question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The sum $10 e^{2 \pi i/11} + 10 e^{15 \pi i/22}$ is expressed as $re^{i \theta}.$  Enter the ordered pair $(r, \theta).$
inference:
Let $z_1 = 10 e^{2 \pi i/11}$ and $z_2 = 10 e^{15 \pi i/22}.$
Then
\begin{align*} z_1 + z_2 &= 10 e^{2 \pi i/11} + 10 e^{15 \pi i/22} \\ &= 10 \left( e^{2 \pi i/11} + e^{15 \pi i/22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( e^{4 \pi i/22} + e^{15 \pi i/22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( e^{4 \pi i/22} + e^{15 \pi i/22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{4 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{4 \pi}{22} + \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{2 \pi}{11} + i \sin \frac{2 \pi}{11} + \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 e^{2 \pi i / 11} + 10 e^{15 \pi i / 22} \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{4 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{4 \pi}{22} \right) + 10 \left( \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{2 \pi}{11} + i \sin \frac{2 \pi}{11} \right) + 10 \left( \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{4 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{4 \pi}{22} \right) + 10 \left( \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left[ \cos \left( \frac{2 \pi}{11} \right) + i \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{11} \right) + \cos \left( \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) + i \sin \left( \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \right] \end{align*}
Using the sum-to-product formulas,
\[ \cos a + \cos b = 2 \cos \frac{a + b}{2} \cos \frac{a - b}{2}. \]
$z_1 + z_2 = 10 \left( 2 \cos \frac{17 \pi / 22}{2} \cos \frac{-11 \pi / 22}{2} \right) = 10 \left( 2 \cos \frac{17 \pi}{44} \cos \frac{-11 \pi}{44} \right).$
$r = 10 \sqrt{2} \cos \left( \frac{2 \pi}{11} + \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) = 10 \sqrt{2} \cos \left( \frac{4 \pi}{22} + \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) = 10 \sqrt{2} \cos \left( \frac{19 \pi}{22} \right)$
$r = 20 \cos \left( \frac{19 \pi}{44} \right).$

Final Answer: $\boxed{(10\sqrt{2}, \frac{19\pi}{22})}$
ground_truth:
The average of $\frac{2 \pi}{11}$ and $\frac{15 \pi}{22}$ is $\frac{19 \pi}{44}.$  We can then write
\begin{align*}
10 e^{2 \pi i/11} + 10 e^{15 \pi i/22} &= 10 e^{19 \pi i/44} (e^{-\pi i/4} + e^{\pi i/4}) \\
&= 10 e^{19 \pi i/44} \left( \cos \frac{\pi}{4} + i \sin \frac{\pi}{4} + \cos \frac{\pi}{4} - i \sin \frac{\pi}{4} \right) \\
&= 10 \sqrt{2} e^{19 \pi i/44}.
\end{align*}Thus, $(r, \theta) = \boxed{\left( 10 \sqrt{2}, \frac{19 \pi}{44} \right)}.$

question:
Let $z_1 = 10 e^{2 \pi i/11}$ and $z_2 = 10 e^{15 \pi i/22}.$
Then
\begin{align*} z_1 + z_2 &= 10 e^{2 \pi i/11} + 10 e^{15 \pi i/22} \\ &= 10 \left( e^{2 \pi i/11} + e^{15 \pi i/22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( e^{4 \pi i/22} + e^{15 \pi i/22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( e^{4 \pi i/22} + e^{15 \pi i/22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{4 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{4 \pi}{22} + \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{2 \pi}{11} + i \sin \frac{2 \pi}{11} + \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 e^{2 \pi i / 11} + 10 e^{15 \pi i / 22} \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{4 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{4 \pi}{22} \right) + 10 \left( \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{2 \pi}{11} + i \sin \frac{2 \pi}{11} \right) + 10 \left( \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left( \cos \frac{4 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{4 \pi}{22} \right) + 10 \left( \cos \frac{15 \pi}{22} + i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \\ &= 10 \left[ \cos \left( \frac{2 \pi}{11} \right) + i \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{11} \right) + \cos \left( \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) + i \sin \left( \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) \right] \end{align*}
Using the sum-to-product formulas,
\[ \cos a + \cos b = 2 \cos \frac{a + b}{2} \cos \frac{a - b}{2}. \]
$z_1 + z_2 = 10 \left( 2 \cos \frac{17 \pi / 22}{2} \cos \frac{-11 \pi / 22}{2} \right) = 10 \left( 2 \cos \frac{17 \pi}{44} \cos \frac{-11 \pi}{44} \right).$
$r = 10 \sqrt{2} \cos \left( \frac{2 \pi}{11} + \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) = 10 \sqrt{2} \cos \left( \frac{4 \pi}{22} + \frac{15 \pi}{22} \right) = 10 \sqrt{2} \cos \left( \frac{19 \pi}{22} \right)$
$r = 20 \cos \left( \frac{19 \pi}{44} \right).$

Final Answer: $\boxed{(10\sqrt{2}, \frac{19\pi}{22})}$

inference:
$z_1 = 10 e^{2\pi i/11}$, $z_2 = 10 e^{15\pi i/22}$.
$z_1 + z_2 = 10(e^{4\pi i/22} + e^{15\pi i/22}) = 10(e^{2\pi i/11} + e^{15\pi i/22})$.
$e^{2\pi i/11} = \cos(2\pi/11) + i \sin(2\pi/11)$.
$e^{15\pi i/22} = \cos(15\pi/22) + i \sin(15\pi/22)$.
We can use the sum-to-product formula for $\cos a + \cos b$: $\cos a + \cos b = 2 \cos(\frac{a+b}{2}) \cos(\frac{a-b}{2})$.

$\cos(2\pi/11) + \cos(15\pi/22) = 2 \cos(\frac{2\pi/11 + 15\pi/22}{2}) \cos(\frac{2\pi/11 - 15\pi/22}{2})$
$= 2 \cos(\frac{19\pi/22}{2}) \cos(\frac{-11\pi/22}{2})$
$= 2 \cos(\frac{19\pi}{44}) \cos(\frac{-11\pi}{44}) = 2 \cos(\frac{19\pi}{44}) \cos(\frac{11\pi}{44}) = 2 \cos(\frac{19\pi}{44}) \cos(\frac{\pi}{4}) = 2 \cos(\frac{19\pi}{44}) \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} = \sqrt{2} \cos(\frac{19\pi}{44})$

The modulus is $10 \sqrt{2} \cos(\frac{19\pi}{44})$.
The argument is $\frac{19\pi}{22}$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{(10\sqrt{2},\frac{19\pi}{22})}$
ground_truth:
The average of $\frac{2 \pi}{11}$ and $\frac{15 \pi}{22}$ is $\frac{19 \pi}{44}.$  We can then write
\begin{align*}
10 e^{2 \pi i/11} + 10 e^{15 \pi i/22} &= 10 e^{19 \pi i/44} (e^{-\pi i/4} + e^{\pi i/4}) \\
&= 10 e^{19 \pi i/44} \left( \cos \frac{\pi}{4} + i \sin \frac{\pi}{4} + \cos \frac{\pi}{4} - i \sin \frac{\pi}{4} \right) \\
&= 10 \sqrt{2} e^{19 \pi i/44}.
\end{align*}Thus, $(r, \theta) = \boxed{\left( 10 \sqrt{2}, \frac{19 \pi}{44} \right)}.$
